page.text: This traffic impact analysis has been prepared for the proposed Lakeside Fire Station #2. The
proposed development is located in the unincorporated County of San Diego in the Lakeside
Community Planning area, east of State Route 67 and just north of the Lakeside central business
The project is adjacent to Lakeside Avenue on the northeast corner of the intersection with Channel
Road. Primary access to the project site is provided by Lakeside Avenue by means of the current
driveway just north of Channel Road, and emergency vehicle access for the fire trucks is will be
provided by a drive-through style driveway traversing the southwest corner of the project. Lakeside
Avenue and Channel Road are arterials that connect the project to other arterials. State Route 67
(SR-67) provides regional access to the project site.
Figure 1-1 shows the project vicinity and study area. Figure 1-2 shows the project site plan.
The project consists of a 10 bunk-room fire station with 8,000 square feet of office space on
approximately 3.5 acres. One occupied estate dwelling unit is currently on the proposed project site.
The study area for this project includes those locations that are expected to be affected by this project.
The scope of the study area is based on the County of San Diego Guidelines and developed through a
review of on-going traffic studies, and a working knowledge of the local transportation system. The
study area is shown in Figure 1-1. The specific study area includes three roadway segments, one
• Lakeside Avenue north of Channel Road
• Lakeside Avenue east of Channel Road
• Channel Road south of Lakeside Avenue
Trip generation is a measure or forecast of the number of trips that begin or end at the project site.
The traffic generated is a function of the extent and type of development proposed for the site. These
trips will result in some traffic increases on the streets where they occur. Vehicular traffic generation
characteristics for projects are estimated based on established rates. These rates identify the probable
traffic generation of various land uses based studies of developments in comparable settings. The
rates used in this analysis were determined based on rates contained in the (SANDAG) (Not So) Brief
Guide of Vehicular Traffic Generation Rates for the San Diego Region (2002). This manual provides
standards and recommendations for the probable traffic generation of various land uses based upon
local, regional and nationwide studies of existing developments in comparable settings. Appendix C
As shown in Table 1-1 the project will generate a net 288 daily trips. The fire station will generate
trips based on the normal daily activities on site. This estimate of trip generation is estimated based
on government office rates and multi-family housing rates. This is a conservative estimate since he
bunk-rooms will house the same fire fighters that work in the office on site. Therefore, some double
counting of trips has occurred. Also, it is estimated that the site will accommodate three fire trucks,
one ambulance and one battalion chief SUV. These trucks only operate in emergency situations and
are not a part of the daily trip generation of the site. Therefore, they are not included as part of the
Source: SANDAG (Not So) Brief Guide of Vehicular Traffic Generation Rates for the San Diego Region
Note: Numbers displayed are to the nearest integer.
Trip distribution and assignment is the process of identifying the probable destinations, directions and
traffic routes that project related traffic will likely affect. Trip distribution and assignment
information can be estimated from observed traffic patterns, experience or through use of a
computerized travel forecast model. Once the proposed developments trips have been estimated, they
are assigned to the study area network. The trip distribution and assignment for this project is based
on observed traffic patterns and engineering judgment.
The trip distribution and assignment for the project-related trips is shown in Figure 1-3. Figure 1-4
shows the daily and peak hour project trips.
The proposed project will take access off Lakeside Avenue via a private easement roadway. Regional
access is provided by State Route 67 (east of the project site). Lakeside Avenue and Channel Road
are arterials that connect the project to the surround freeways. More detailed information regarding
the project access operations and safety can be found in Chapter 5.
The project is proposed with 31 on-site parking spaces. The project is also proposed to house up to
three fire trucks, one ambulance and one SUV operated by the Battalion Chief.
*Volumes could be off due to rounding
*Volumes could be off due to rounding
This chapter documents the methodologies and assumptions used to conduct the traffic impact
analysis for the project. The study methodology and analysis is based on the County of San Diego
Report Format and Content Requirements (Transportation and Traffic) and the County of San Diego
Guidelines for Determining Significance (Transportation and Traffic) both adopted in June 30, 2009.
The guidelines are used to determine the project’s conformance with County of San Diego Public
Facility Element policies and evaluate whether a project’s impacts are perceptible to the average
driver. This section contains the following background information:
This report presents an analysis of the following analysis scenarios:
Street system operating conditions are typically described in terms of “level of service.” Level of
service is a report-card scale used to indicate the quality of traffic flow on roadway segments and at
intersections. Level of service (LOS) ranges from LOS A (free flow, little congestion) to LOS F
(forced flow, extreme congestion). A more detailed description of the concepts described in this
section is provided in Appendix A of this document. The following methods are outlined in this
publication and used in this study.
The County of San Diego has published daily traffic volume standards for roadways within its
jurisdiction. To determine service levels on study area roadway segments, we compared the
appropriate average daily traffic thresholds for level of service to the daily capacity of the study area
roadway segments, and the existing and future volumes in the study area. The thresholds for
determining level of service used in this analysis are summarized in Appendix A.
The analysis of peak hour intersection performance was conducted using the Traffix analysis software
program, which uses methodologies defined in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) to
calculate results. Level of service (LOS) for intersections is determined by control delay. Control
delay is defined as the total elapsed time from when a vehicle stops at the end of a queue to the time
the vehicle departs from the stop line. The total elapsed time includes the time required for the vehicle
to travel from the last-in-queue position to the first-in-queue position, including deceleration of
vehicles from free-flow speed to the speed of vehicles in the queue. Appendix A lists the HCM
delay/LOS criteria for both signalized and unsignalized intersections.
The HCM analysis methodology for evaluating signalized intersections is based on the “operational
analysis” procedure. This technique uses 1,900 passenger cars per hour of green per lane (pcphgpl) as
the maximum saturation flow of a single lane at an intersection. This saturation flow rate is adjusted
to account for lane width, on-street parking, conflicting pedestrian flow, traffic composition, (e.g., the
percentage of vehicles that are trucks) and shared lane movements (e.g., through and right-turn
movements from the same lane). Average control delay is calculated by taking a volume-weighted
average of all the delays for all vehicles entering the intersection.
The HCM analysis methodology for evaluating two-way stop-controlled (TWSC) intersections is
based on gap acceptance and conflicting traffic for vehicles stopped on the minor-street approaches.
The critical gap (or minimum gap that would be acceptable) is defined as the minimum time interval
in the major-street traffic stream that allows intersection entry for one minor-street vehicle. Average
control delay and LOS for the “worst approach” are reported. Level of service is not defined for the
To determine direct project impacts, the County of San Diego has developed a series of thresholds
based on allowable increases in volume-to-capacity ratios that become more stringent as level of
service worsens. The County of San Diego significance thresholds are used. Appendix A summarizes
these thresholds. Where roadway segments and intersections operate at LOS D or better impacts are
The June 30, 2009 Guidelines define the threshold of significance as on average the addition of one
minutes during peak hour conditions depending on the level of service of
the roadway. In most cases, this increase would result in changes to traffic flow that would not be
noticeable to the average driver and, therefore, would not constitute a significant impact on the

text.b: County of San Diego Public Facilities Element Policy

page.text: The following policies are from the San Diego County General Plan Part XII Public Facilities
Element which was adopted March 13, 1991 and amended October 28, 1993.
Policy 1.1: New development shall provide needed roadway expansion and improvements on-site to
meet the demand created by the development, and to maintain a Level of Service “C” on Circulation
Element Roads during peak traffic hours. New development shall provide off-site improvements
designed to contribute to the overall achievement of a Level of Service “D” on Circulation Element
Policy 1.2: General Plan Amendments and Rezones shall be reviewed to ensure that any proposed
increases in density or intensity of use will not prevent the planned Circulation Element road system
from operating at its planned Level of Service at buildout.
The intersection turning movement counts were conducted during the weekday morning peak period
from 7:00 AM to 9:00 AM and during the weekday evening peak period from 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM in
July 2009. Average daily traffic volumes were obtained through machine data collection. Since
schools were on summer break when the traffic counts were conducted, traffic from nearby schools is
forecasted and added to the counted volumes to create the existing baseline volumes. Appendix F
contains the details of the school trip distribution and assignment. The resultant existing weekday
morning and evening peak hour intersection volumes are shown in Figures 3-2 and 3-3. The daily
traffic volumes are shown in Figure 3-4. Project traffic is added to the existing base volumes to
The principal roadways in the project study area are described briefly below. The description includes
the physical characteristics, adjacent land uses, and traffic control devices along these roadways. The
existing roadway geometry and control conditions are shown in Figure 3-1. Additional details
regarding specific intersection operating conditions can be found on the capacity analysis worksheets
Lakeside Avenue runs east/west connecting the City of Santee to the Community of Lakeside.
Lakeside Avenue north of Channel Road functions as a Town Collector with one lane in each
direction with a two-way center turn lane. Lakeside Avenue east of Channel Road functions as a
Light Collector with one lane in each direction. North of Channel Road the roadway has an ultimate
classification of a Collector with 2 lanes in each direction. East of Channel Road the roadway is built
to its ultimate classification. The roadway provides driveway access to adjacent land uses. The
adjacent land uses on the road includes residential and industrial. The posted speed limit is 40 MPH.
The frontage at the project will be improved consistent with the ultimate roadway requirements to the
Channel Road runs north/south connecting the Community of Lakeside. It functions as a Major Road
with two lanes in each direction with a two-way center turn lane. This roadway is built to its ultimate
classification. The roadway provides driveway access to adjacent land uses. The posted speed limit is

The County of San Diego has developed an overall programmatic solution that addressed existing and
projected future road deficiencies in the unincorporated portion of San Diego County. This program
includes the adoption of a Transportation Impact Fee (TIF) program to fund improvements to
roadways necessary to mitigate potential cumulative impacts caused by traffic from future
development. Based on SANDAG regional growth and land use forecasts, the SANDAG Regional
Transportation Model was utilized to analyze projected build-out (year 2030) development conditions
on the existing circulation element roadway network throughout the unincorporated area of the
County. Based on the results of the traffic modeling, funding necessary to construct transportation
facilities that will mitigate cumulative impacts from new development was identified. Existing
roadway deficiencies will be corrected through improvement projects funded by other public funding
sources, such as TransNet, gas tax, and grants. Potential cumulative impacts to the region’s freeways
have been addressed in SANDAG’s Regional Transportation Plan (RTP). This plan, which considers
freeway buildout over the next 30 years, will use funds from TransNet, state, and federal funding to
improve freeways to projected level of service objectives in the RTP.
The proposed project generates 288 daily trips. These trips will be distributed on circulation element
roadways in the County that were analyzed by the TIF program, some of which currently or are
projected to operate at inadequate levels of service. These project trips therefore contribute to a
potential significant cumulative impact and mitigation is required. The potential growth represented
by this project was included in the growth projections upon which the TIF program is based.
Therefore, payment of the TIF, which will be required at issuance of building permits, in combination
with other components of the program described above, will mitigate potential cumulative traffic
The project will access the local roadway network via three driveways. Two driveways are separated
driveways for emergency vehicles only. These driveways will be used by emergency vehicles only,
which includes the three fire trucks, one ambulance and one battalion chief SUV. Both emergency
driveways will provide full access in order to minimize the emergency response times of the
emergency vehicles. During emergency responses the emergency vehicles utilize their sirens and
flashing lights to provide better visibility and indicate to other drivers that emergency vehicles are
approaching. These additional safety features reduce the need for deceleration and acceleration lanes
The north most driveway at the western property line on Lakeside Avenue north of Channel Road is
an existing driveway that provides access to several single family homes and the proposed parking for
the fire station employees. This driveway is directly adjacent to the emergency access driveway and
does not meet the County of San Diego minimum driveway spacing requirements. However, it is
important to maintain a completely separated emergency vehicle driveway in order to allow for the
quickest ingress/egress in the event of an emergency. Also, the emergency driveway is only used in
emergency situations or infrequently for other situations that require the use of the emergency
vehicles. Therefore, consolidating the two proposed adjacent driveways on Lakeside Drive north of
Channel Road is not recommended. This would require a design modification request.
The sight distance at the project accesses onto Lakeside Avenue were analyzed for sight distance
The posted speed on Lakeside Avenue and Channel Road is 40 miles per hour. This speed plus 5 mph
(45 mph) was used as the prevailing speed in order to determine the required corner and stopping
sight distances for the western driveways along Lake Side Avenue between Channel Road and Valle
Vista Road. A Speed survey was conducted to determine the prevailing speed on Lakeside Avenue
east of Channel Road. The speed survey determined that there was a prevailing speed of 41 mph on
Lakeside Avenue east of the southern project driveway. Please see Appendix E for the speed survey
Intersection corner sight distance criteria from the San Diego County Standards for Private Roads
(Page 10) were applied. According to the County of San Diego Private Road Standards, the prevailing
speed of 45 mph on Lakeside Avenue and Channel Road requires a minimum corner sight distance of
450 feet. The prevailing speed of 41 mph on Lakeside Avenue East of Channel Road requires a
minimum corner sight distance of 410 feet. Sight distance is measured with an object height of 4.25
feet and an eye height of 3.5 feet.
The stopping sight distance was calculated using the prevailing speed and AASHTO guidelines to
account for the slope. There is a +1.7% grade slope heading north from the Western Driveway. There
is a +1.0% grade slope heading east from the Southern Driveway. Stopping sight distance is
calculated with an object height of 2.0 feet and an eye height of 3.5 feet.
Table 5-1 summarizes the sight distance requirements and results of field measurements. Sight
distance is met for corner sight and stopping sight at all locations except for the following:
• Southern Driveway / Lakeside Avenue east of the driveway.

Corner sight conclusion: There is a deficiency of 165 feet in sight distance. The sight
distance towards the east is horizontally constrained by a hillside on the north side of
Lakeside Avenue east of Channel Road.
Stopping sight conclusion: There is a deficiency of 75 feet in sight distance. The sight
distance towards the east is horizontally constrained by a hillside on the north side of
Lakeside Avenue east of Channel Road.
The following photographs depict the sight distance at two of the driveways.
Looking south from the Western Driveway along Lakeside Avenue, the driveway provides a corner
sight distance greater than 600 feet observed at 10 feet from the edge of pavement. Looking north
from the Western Driveway along Lakeside Avenue, the driveway provides a corner sight distance
greater than 600 feet observed at 10 feet from the edge of pavement.
Looking east from the Southern Driveway along Lakeside Avenue, the driveway provides a corner
sight distance of 285 feet observed at 10 feet from the edge of pavement. Looking east from the
Southern Driveway along Lakeside Avenue, the driveway provides a stopping sight distance of 295
feet observed at the edge of pavement.

The concept of LOS is defined as a qualitative measure describing operational conditions within a traffic
stream, and the motorist's and/or passengers' perception of operations. A LOS definition generally
describes these conditions in terms of such factors as speed, travel time, freedom to maneuver, comfort,
convenience, and safety. Levels of service for freeway segments can generally be categorized as shown in
San Diego County Roadway Classifications, Levels of Service (LOS) and
The concept of LOS is defined as a qualitative measure describing operational conditions within a traffic
stream, and the motorist's and/or passengers' perception of operations. A LOS definition generally
describes these conditions in terms of such factors as speed, travel time, freedom to maneuver, comfort,
convenience, and safety. Levels of service for arterial segments with a range of free-flow speeds can
generally be categorized as shown in the table above.

text.b: Highway Capacity Manual Operational Analysis Method

page.text: The operational analysis method for evaluation of signalized intersections presented in the 2000 Highway
Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board Special Report 209) defines level of service in terms of
delay, or more specifically, control stopped delay per vehicle. Delay is a measure of driver and/or
passenger discomfort, frustration, fuel consumption, and lost travel time.
LOS A describes operations with very low delay. This occurs when progression is extremely favorable, and
most vehicles do not stop at all. Short cycle lengths may also contribute to low delay.
LOS B describes operations with generally good progression and/or short cycle lengths. More vehicles stop
than for LOS A, causing higher levels of average delay.
LOS C describes operations with higher delays, which may result from fair progression and/or longer cycle
lengths. Individual cycle failures may begin to appear at this level. The number of vehicles stopping is
significant at this level, although many still pass through the intersection without stopping.
LOS D describes operations with high delay, resulting from some combination of unfavorable progression,
long cycle lengths, or high volumes. The influence of congestion becomes more noticeable, and individual
LOS E is considered to be the limit of acceptable delay. Individual cycle failures are frequent occurrences.
LOS F describes a condition of excessively high delay, considered unacceptable to most drivers. This
condition often occurs when arrival flow rates exceed the capacity of the intersection. Poor progression and
long cycle lengths may also be major contributing causes to such delay.

text.b: MINOR STREET STOP AND ALL-WAY STOP CONTROLLED INTERSECTION LEVEL OF SERVICE
HIGHWAY CAPACITY MANUAL OPERATIONAL ANALYSIS METHOD

page.text: The Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) analysis method for evaluating minor street stop intersections is
based on the average total delay for each impeded movement. For all-way stop controlled intersections it
is based on the average total delay for the entire intersection. As used here, total delay is defined as the
total elapsed time from when a when a vehicle stops at the end of a queue until the vehicle departs from
the stop line; this time includes the time required for the vehicle to travel from the last-in-queue to the
first-in-queue position. The average total delay for any particular minor movement is a function of the
service rate or capacity of the approach and the degree of saturation. The resulting delay is used to
determine the level of service as shown in the following table.
LOS A – Little or no delay
LOS E – Very long traffic delays
LOS F – When the demand exceeds the capacity of the lane, extreme delays will be encountered and
queuing may cause severe congestion to the intersection.
Note: A critical movement is one that is experiencing excessive queues.
